Award.AwardTitle: Stochastic Agent-based Modeling of Angiogenesis and Tissue Growth

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0731201
Cinar
This project will combine in vitro and in vivo (animal model) experimental studies in order to develop new models for angiogenesis in engineered tissues. The research results will contribute to the knowledge base in simulation-based engineering science and in dynamic modeling of stochastic complex biomedical systems. In addition, knowledge acquired in this research will provide important insight into mechanism governing angiogenesis in engineered tissues. The outcome of the research will be new strategies, methods, and tools: (1) To develop multi-scale, agent-based predictive models for conducting in silico experiments and optimize values of factors for angiogenesis and tissue growth; (2) To assess the impact of stochastic effects on the dynamics of angiogenesis and tissue growth, and conduct sensitivity analysis; and (3) To develop in vitro and in vivo experimental techniques to validate model predictions and therapy protocols. Mathematical models that can predict the rate and extent of angiogenesis in engineered tissues based on soluble and physical factors will reduce guesswork in tissue engineering therapy and ultimately enable the selection of the best tissue growth conditions for a specific individual and tissue or organ.

The proposed activity also contributes to promoting education and training in modeling of complex dynamic stochastic systems, hierarchical agent-based models, and angiogenesis and tissue engineering. Furthermore, the techniques for model development and assessment of the effects of stochastic variations can be used in complex adaptive systems in many fields central to national and global concerns. Significant effort will be devoted to disseminate research results in the form of software, case studies, and practical training to researchers and graduate students, K-12 teachers, undergraduate students and students from underrepresented groups in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Three-dimensional Modeling of Angiogenesis in Porous Biomaterial Scaffolds

Porous biomaterial scaffolds serve as a substrate for tissue growth, providing mechanical and structural support during tissue development. Vascularization of porous scaffolds is critical and is a limiting barrier in the development of clinically-applicable replacement tissues. Angiogenesis, the formation of new capillaries from pre-existing blood vessels, is the primary mechanism for vascularization of tissue engineering biomaterials. The structure and characteristics of polymer scaffolds play an important role in angiogenesis and tissue growth. Numerous design parameters need to be considered and optimized to produce scaffolds that promote the growth of functional blood vessels. This project enabled the development of an engineering design method that integrates the design of a scaffold with well-defined properties, simulation of angiogenesis with the designed scaffold and evaluation of the simulation results to select promising scaffold designs for experimental studies. This design process reduces the daunting task of considering and optimizing many design factors in experimental studies.

The use of simulations has increased in recent years to better understand complex biomedical phenomena, to predict the outcomes of experiments and to generate rapid results that may inspire new hypotheses that can be tested experimentally. Agent-based models (ABMs) provide an innovative approach for simulating and understanding complex biological systems through development of rule-based computational framework. The development of biomedical ABMs involves the definition of agents that can represent biological cells and the development of rules that describe cell behavior and regulate interactions among cell agents.  Complex biomedical ABMs are difficult to build and validate. However, once validated to yield realistic results, they can be used to analyze the effects of a vast number of variables and their interactions. ABMs benefit from a high level of modularity; researchers can start with a simple model and add details to the model over time to increase its capabilities.

In ABMs, cells are represented by independent individual software entities acting in their microenvironment, responding to factors present in the environment (e.g. scaffolds, ligands, soluble factors) and interacting with their neighboring cells to generate higher-level emergent behavior. ABMs are especially suitable for modeling biological systems as their building blocks are individual discrete constituents (e.g. cells) that interact with each other to form higher level (tissue and organ level) behavior. A 3D ABM is developed to model the process of sprouting angiogenesis within porous polymeric scaffolds. The model can be used to test various strategies for vascularization of engineered tissues.  As the techniques for generating scaffolds with exact pore architectures and tools for characterizing the macroporous architecture of generated scaffolds advance, simulation systems provide a powerful environment that enables the investigation of optimal scaffold parameters that maximize blood vessel formation and speed up in-depth ingrowth (Figure 1). As we hypothesized, the physical characteristics of biomaterials such as pore size, interconnectivity, porosity, and pore size distribution impact blood vessel formation and ingrowth.

The ABM simulations rely on a scaffold model that provides well-defined parameters to characterize biomaterial scaffolds. Pore size, size distribution can be assigned, interconnectivity and porosity can be determined and images can be generated.  These images are used to describe the scaffold for angiogenesis simulation. The ABM developed can also use confocal laser scanning microscopy images of real scaffolds (instead of theoretical model sca...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Three-dimensional Modeling of Angiogenesis in Porous Biomaterial Scaffolds Porous biomaterial scaffolds serve as a substrate for tissue growth, providing mechanical and structural support during tissue development. Vascularization of porous scaffolds is critical and is a limiting barrier in the development of clinically-applicable replacement tissues. Angiogenesis, the formation of new capillaries from pre-existing blood vessels, is the primary mechanism for vascularization of tissue engineering biomaterials. The structure and characteristics of polymer scaffolds play an important role in angiogenesis and tissue growth. Numerous design parameters need to be considered and optimized to produce scaffolds that promote the growth of functional blood vessels. This project enabled the development of an engineering design method that integrates the design of a scaffold with well-defined properties, simulation of angiogenesis with the designed scaffold and evaluation of the simulation results to select promising scaffold designs for experimental studies. This design process reduces the daunting task of considering and optimizing many design factors in experimental studies. The use of simulations has increased in recent years to better understand complex biomedical phenomena, to predict the outcomes of experiments and to generate rapid results that may inspire new hypotheses that can be tested experimentally. Agent-based models (ABMs) provide an innovative approach for simulating and understanding complex biological systems through development of rule-based computational framework. The development of biomedical ABMs involves the definition of agents that can represent biological cells and the development of rules that describe cell behavior and regulate interactions among cell agents. Complex biomedical ABMs are difficult to build and validate. However, once validated to yield realistic results, they can be used to analyze the effects of a vast number of variables and their interactions. ABMs benefit from a high level of modularity; researchers can start with a simple model and add details to the model over time to increase its capabilities. In ABMs, cells are represented by independent individual software entities acting in their microenvironment, responding to factors present in the environment (e.g. scaffolds, ligands, soluble factors) and interacting with their neighboring cells to generate higher-level emergent behavior. ABMs are especially suitable for modeling biological systems as their building blocks are individual discrete constituents (e.g. cells) that interact with each other to form higher level (tissue and organ level) behavior. A 3D ABM is developed to model the process of sprouting angiogenesis within porous polymeric scaffolds. The model can be used to test various strategies for vascularization of engineered tissues. As the techniques for generating scaffolds with exact pore architectures and tools for characterizing the macroporous architecture of generated scaffolds advance, simulation systems provide a powerful environment that enables the investigation of optimal scaffold parameters that maximize blood vessel formation and speed up in-depth ingrowth (Figure 1). As we hypothesized, the physical characteristics of biomaterials such as pore size, interconnectivity, porosity, and pore size distribution impact blood vessel formation and ingrowth. The ABM simulations rely on a scaffold model that provides well-defined parameters to characterize biomaterial scaffolds. Pore size, size distribution can be assigned, interconnectivity and porosity can be determined and images can be generated. These images are used to describe the scaffold for angiogenesis simulation. The ABM developed can also use confocal laser scanning microscopy images of real scaffolds (instead of theoretical model scaffolds).
